summary.long: Micah is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: The word of the Lord that came to Micah of Moresheth during the reigns of Jotham, Ahaz and Hezekiah, kings of Judah—the vision he saw concerning Samaria and Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Hear, you peoples, all of you,
    listen, earth and all who live in it,
that the Sovereign Lord may bear witness against you,
    the Lord from his holy temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look! The Lord is coming from his dwelling place;
    he comes down and treads on the heights of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The mountains melt beneath him
    and the valleys split apart,
like wax before the fire,
    like water rushing down a slope.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All this is because of Jacob’s transgression,
    because of the sins of the people of Israel.
What is Jacob’s transgression?
    Is it not Samaria?
What is Judah’s high place?
    Is it not Jerusalem?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Therefore I will make Samaria a heap of rubble,
    a place for planting vineyards.
I will pour her stones into the valley
    and lay bare her foundations.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Because of this I will weep and wail;
    I will go about barefoot and naked.
I will howl like a jackal
    and moan like an owl.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For Samaria’s plague is incurable;
    it has spread to Judah.
It has reached the very gate of my people,
    even to Jerusalem itself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Tell it not in Gath;
    weep not at all.
In Beth Ophrah
    roll in the dust.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Pass by naked and in shame,
    you who live in Shaphir.
Those who live in Zaanan
    will not come out.
Beth Ezel is in mourning;
    it no longer protects you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those who live in Maroth writhe in pain,
    waiting for relief,
because disaster has come from the Lord,
    even to the gate of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You who live in Lachish,
    harness fast horses to the chariot.
You are where the sin of Daughter Zion began,
    for the transgressions of Israel were found in you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore you will give parting gifts
    to Moresheth Gath.
The town of Akzib will prove deceptive
    to the kings of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will bring a conqueror against you
    who live in Mareshah.
The nobles of Israel
    will flee to Adullam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Shave your head in mourning
    for the children in whom you delight;
make yourself as bald as the vulture,
    for they will go from you into exile.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Woe to those who plan iniquity,
    to those who plot evil on their beds!
At morning’s light they carry it out
    because it is in their power to do it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They covet fields and seize them,
    and houses, and take them.
They defraud people of their homes,
    they rob them of their inheritance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore, the Lord says:
“I am planning disaster against this people,
    from which you cannot save yourselves.
You will no longer walk proudly,
    for it will be a time of calamity.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore you will have no one in the assembly of the Lord
    to divide the land by lot.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
You descendants of Jacob, should it be said,
    “Does the Lord become impatient?
    Does he do such things?”
“Do not my words do good
    to the one whose ways are upright?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Lately my people have risen up
    like an enemy.
You strip off the rich robe
    from those who pass by without a care,
    like men returning from battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You drive the women of my people
    from their pleasant homes.
You take away my blessing
    from their children forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Get up, go away!
    For this is not your resting place,
because it is defiled,
    it is ruined, beyond all remedy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If a liar and deceiver comes and says,
    ‘I will prophesy for you plenty of wine and beer,’
    that would be just the prophet for this people!
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
The One who breaks open the way will go up before them;
    they will break through the gate and go out.
Their King will pass through before them,
    the Lord at their head.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then I said,
“Listen, you leaders of Jacob,
    you rulers of Israel.
Should you not embrace justice,
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
who eat my people’s flesh,
    strip off their skin
    and break their bones in pieces;
who chop them up like meat for the pan,
    like flesh for the pot?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then they will cry out to the Lord,
    but he will not answer them.
At that time he will hide his face from them
    because of the evil they have done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord says:
“As for the prophets
    who lead my people astray,
they proclaim ‘peace’
    if they have something to eat,
but prepare to wage war against anyone
    who refuses to feed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore night will come over you, without visions,
    and darkness, without divination.
The sun will set for the prophets,
    and the day will go dark for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The seers will be ashamed
    and the diviners disgraced.
They will all cover their faces
    because there is no answer from God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But as for me, I am filled with power,
    with the Spirit of the Lord,
    and with justice and might,
to declare to Jacob his transgression,
    to Israel his sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Hear this, you leaders of Jacob,
    you rulers of Israel,
who despise justice
    and distort all that is right;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
who build Zion with bloodshed,
    and Jerusalem with wickedness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Her leaders judge for a bribe,
    her priests teach for a price,
    and her prophets tell fortunes for money.
Yet they look for the Lord’s support and say,
    “Is not the Lord among us?
    No disaster will come upon us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore because of you,
    Zion will be plowed like a field,
Jerusalem will become a heap of rubble,
    the temple hill a mound overgrown with thickets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In the last days
the mountain of the Lord’s temple will be established
    as the highest of the mountains;
it will be exalted above the hills,
    and peoples will stream to it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Many nations will come and say,
“Come, let us go up to the mountain of the Lord,
    to the temple of the God of Jacob.
He will teach us his ways,
    so that we may walk in his paths.”
The law will go out from Zion,
    the word of the Lord from Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will judge between many peoples
    and will settle disputes for strong nations far and wide.
They will beat their swords into plowshares
    and their spears into pruning hooks.
Nation will not take up sword against nation,
    nor will they train for war anymore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Everyone will sit under their own vine
    and under their own fig tree,
and no one will make them afraid,
    for the Lord Almighty has spoken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All the nations may walk
    in the name of their gods,
but we will walk in the name of the Lord
    our God for ever and ever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“In that day,” declares the Lord,
“I will gather the lame;
    I will assemble the exiles
    and those I have brought to grief.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will make the lame my remnant,
    those driven away a strong nation.
The Lord will rule over them in Mount Zion
    from that day and forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As for you, watchtower of the flock,
    stronghold of Daughter Zion,
the former dominion will be restored to you;
    kingship will come to Daughter Jerusalem.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why do you now cry aloud—
    have you no king?
Has your ruler perished,
    that pain seizes you like that of a woman in labor?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Writhe in agony, Daughter Zion,
    like a woman in labor,
for now you must leave the city
    to camp in the open field.
You will go to Babylon;
    there you will be rescued.
There the Lord will redeem you
    out of the hand of your enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But now many nations
    are gathered against you.
They say, “Let her be defiled,
    let our eyes gloat over Zion!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But they do not know
    the thoughts of the Lord;
they do not understand his plan,
    that he has gathered them like sheaves to the threshing floor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Rise and thresh, Daughter Zion,
    for I will give you horns of iron;
I will give you hooves of bronze,
    and you will break to pieces many nations.”
You will devote their ill-gotten gains to the Lord,
    their wealth to the Lord of all the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Marshal your troops now, city of troops,
    for a siege is laid against us.
They will strike Israel’s ruler
    on the cheek with a rod.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“But you, Bethlehem Ephrathah,
    though you are small among the clans of Judah,
out of you will come for me
    one who will be ruler over Israel,
whose origins are from of old,
    from ancient times.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore Israel will be abandoned
    until the time when she who is in labor bears a son,
and the rest of his brothers return
    to join the Israelites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will stand and shepherd his flock
    in the strength of the Lord,
    in the majesty of the name of the Lord his God.
And they will live securely, for then his greatness
    will reach to the ends of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And he will be our peace
    when the Assyrians invade our land
    and march through our fortresses.
We will raise against them seven shepherds,
    even eight commanders,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
who will rule the land of Assyria with the sword,
    the land of Nimrod with drawn sword.
He will deliver us from the Assyrians
    when they invade our land
    and march across our borders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The remnant of Jacob will be
    in the midst of many peoples
like dew from the Lord,
    like showers on the grass,
which do not wait for anyone
    or depend on man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The remnant of Jacob will be among the nations,
    in the midst of many peoples,
like a lion among the beasts of the forest,
    like a young lion among flocks of sheep,
which mauls and mangles as it goes,
    and no one can rescue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your hand will be lifted up in triumph over your enemies,
    and all your foes will be destroyed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“In that day,” declares the Lord,
“I will destroy your horses from among you
    and demolish your chariots.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will destroy the cities of your land
    and tear down all your strongholds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will destroy your witchcraft
    and you will no longer cast spells.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will destroy your idols
    and your sacred stones from among you;
you will no longer bow down
    to the work of your hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will uproot from among you your Asherah poles
    when I demolish your cities.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will take vengeance in anger and wrath
    on the nations that have not obeyed me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
“My people, what have I done to you?
    How have I burdened you? Answer me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I brought you up out of Egypt
    and redeemed you from the land of slavery.
I sent Moses to lead you,
    also Aaron and Miriam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My people, remember
    what Balak king of Moab plotted
    and what Balaam son of Beor answered.
Remember your journey from Shittim to Gilgal,
    that you may know the righteous acts of the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
With what shall I come before the Lord
    and bow down before the exalted God?
Shall I come before him with burnt offerings,
    with calves a year old?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will the Lord be pleased with thousands of rams,
    with ten thousand rivers of olive oil?
Shall I offer my firstborn for my transgression,
    the fruit of my body for the sin of my soul?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He has shown you, O mortal, what is good.
    And what does the Lord require of you?
To act justly and to love mercy
    and to walk humbly with your God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen! The Lord is calling to the city—
    and to fear your name is wisdom—
    “Heed the rod and the One who appointed it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Am I still to forget your ill-gotten treasures, you wicked house,
    and the short ephah, which is accursed?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Shall I acquit someone with dishonest scales,
    with a bag of false weights?
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore, I have begun to destroy you,
    to ruin you because of your sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will eat but not be satisfied;
    your stomach will still be empty.
You will store up but save nothing,
    because what you save I will give to the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
What misery is mine!
I am like one who gathers summer fruit
    at the gleaning of the vineyard;
there is no cluster of grapes to eat,
    none of the early figs that I crave.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Both hands are skilled in doing evil;
    the ruler demands gifts,
the judge accepts bribes,
    the powerful dictate what they desire—
    they all conspire together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The best of them is like a brier,
    the most upright worse than a thorn hedge.
The day God visits you has come,
    the day your watchmen sound the alarm.
    Now is the time of your confusion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not trust a neighbor;
    put no confidence in a friend.
Even with the woman who lies in your embrace
    guard the words of your lips.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For a son dishonors his father,
    a daughter rises up against her mother,
a daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law—
    a man’s enemies are the members of his own household.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Do not gloat over me, my enemy!
    Though I have fallen, I will rise.
Though I sit in darkness,
    the Lord will be my light.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Because I have sinned against him,
    I will bear the Lord’s wrath,
until he pleads my case
    and upholds my cause.
He will bring me out into the light;
    I will see his righteousness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then my enemy will see it
    and will be covered with shame,
she who said to me,
    “Where is the Lord your God?”
My eyes will see her downfall;
    even now she will be trampled underfoot
    like mire in the streets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The day for building your walls will come,
    the day for extending your boundaries.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In that day people will come to you
    from Assyria and the cities of Egypt,
even from Egypt to the Euphrates
    and from sea to sea
    and from mountain to mountain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The earth will become desolate because of its inhabitants,
    as the result of their deeds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Shepherd your people with your staff,
    the flock of your inheritance,
which lives by itself in a forest,
    in fertile pasturelands.
Let them feed in Bashan and Gilead
    as in days long ago.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“As in the days when you came out of Egypt,
    I will show them my wonders.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Nations will see and be ashamed,
    deprived of all their power.
They will put their hands over their mouths
    and their ears will become deaf.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They will lick dust like a snake,
    like creatures that crawl on the ground.
They will come trembling out of their dens;
    they will turn in fear to the Lord our God
    and will be afraid of you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who is a God like you,
    who pardons sin and forgives the transgression
    of the remnant of his inheritance?
You do not stay angry forever
    but delight to show mercy.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
You will be faithful to Jacob,
    and show love to Abraham,
as you pledged on oath to our ancestors
    in days long ago.
verses.speaker: Narrator
